name: Shreya KC
description:
Hi! I am Shreya KC, a passionate climate justice activist from Nepal. I have collaborated with young people worldwide to advocate for youth involvement in decision-making and climate education. Currently, I serve as the Advocacy Coordinator for the Loss and Damage Youth Coalition, leading campaigns and building youth capacity on climate-induced loss and damage. I also manage projects and develop campaigns on clean energy and climate change as a Policy Advisor at Clean Energy Nepal. Additionally, I engage with global and local youth networks as a Youth Advisor for The Iris Project and mentor prize winners.
My previous roles include being a member of the EE 30 Under 30 program by North American Association for Environmental Education (NAAEE), and a Board Member at Clean Energy Nepal. I volunteered for the NDC Project at Care About Climate and worked with YOUNGO as the Contact Point for the Nationally Determined Contributions Working Group. I coordinated campaigns and served as a delegate for Mock COP26 and represented Nepal as a Youth Delegate at COP26 and COP25. I was a Youth Climate Change Champion for UNICEF, participated in various youth conferences, and worked on youth-led climate initiatives. My early career involved roles such as Network Coordinator and School and College Coordinator for NYCA Nepal, and I also taught science and environment at Himchuli English Higher Secondary School. Throughout my career, I have been committed to driving meaningful climate action and empowering young people to lead the charge in climate justice.
My story has been featured in 'Stone Soup for a Sustainable World' and '50 Girls Saving Our Planet.' In 2022, I received the 'Youth of the Year' award for my climate action efforts. In my spare time, I love reading, traveling to natural places, and catching up on sleep.

name: Abhishek Shrestha
description:
Abhishek Shrestha is a Co-founder of Digo Bikas Institute and leads Climate justice Program at Institute. He is a Chevening Scholar who graduated in Masters in Climate Change and policy from the University of Sussex, UK in 2013 and BSc. Environmental Science from Kathmandu University in 2008.
He received the “Climate Change Award” in 2017 from the Government of Nepal for his work on Climate Change Policy and Advocacy. He has decade-long experience working as an activist, researcher, campaigner, policy analyst, and strategic communicator at a national and international level on climate change and environmental governance. He has been awarded “JWH Initiative Environment leadership Award 2017.
He follows UN Climate Negotiation closely and has been participating since 2009, COP 15, and attended 8 COP meetings until COP 25 as a Youth representative, CSO representative, and Government delegation. He has been working with diverse national and international climate justice groups since 2008. He has worked as Contributing Author for Government of Nepal publication on “ Key Issues for Nepal at different UN Climate Conference meetings and member of Government delegation at UN Climate Conference in Bonn 2017 (COP 23).
Abhishek has travelled to over 20 countries in Asia, Europe, Africa, South America, and North America and was invited to speak at different national and international conferences on the issue of climate change, climate activism, community solutions, and movement building. He was elected to Serve as YOUNGO Focal Point from Global South for 2012-2013 and interim focal point in COP-17, Durban (YOUNGO- Youth constituency at UNFCCC to ensure positive and constructive participation of the international youth in the UNFCCC) and is a British Council International Climate Champion 2010. He is the Coordinator of Nepal Environment Society- Province 1 and General Secretary of Chevening Alumni Association Nepal. He follows international and Nepal Cricket Closely.

name: Arnab Chaudary
description:
Arnab Chaudhary, a 25-year-old indigenous Tharu community member, is a dedicated advocate in the Climate and Environment Justice Movement.
He passionately champions these causes, particularly from the perspective of indigenous youth. Arnab is not only active in the courtroom, advocating for climate, environmental justice, and the rights of marginalized communities, but also a creative individual with a love for poetry, storytelling, and literature. His inquisitive mind fosters lively discussions on political, social, and environmental issues. Arnab is a staunch supporter of preserving indigenous languages, culture, and rights, as well as the rights of minority groups. He is committed to empowering both youth and communities to drive positive change. Arnab's central focus is on policy-making, public interest litigation, and advocacy, using his legal expertise to advance climate, environmental justice, and the rights of indigenous and underprivileged people.
Currently, he holds key positions in organizations such as a member of the U.S. Embassy Youth Council Nepal, Operation Director at Harin Nepal, Board Member at All in Foundation, and Executive Secretary at Dang Society.

name: Sagar Koirala
description:
Sagar Koirala is an influential youth leader and environmental advocate, known for his extensive involvement in various global initiatives aimed at fostering sustainable development, empowering young people, and promoting environmental conservation. His journey is marked by a series of significant roles across numerous organizations, each reflecting his commitment to making a positive impact on the world.
Currently, Sagar serves as the Regional Focal Point for the Asia Pacific at the Sendai Stakeholders Children and Youth Group. He is also a member of Young Water Professionals Nepal and the Groundwater Youth Network in Paris, contributing to innovative water management solutions. Sagar's mentorship extends to organizations like Wedu and the Asian Environmental Youth Network, empowering young individuals to drive social change. His roles with the International Republican Institute's Generation Democracy program and as a Student Energy Fellow underscore his commitment to democratic governance, civic participation, and sustainable energy solutions. Additionally, he has significantly contributed to food sustainability as a Youth Ambassador for Real Food Systems and as a member of the United Nations Major Group for Children and Youth since 2019.
Sagar's academic background in agriculture from Agriculture and Forestry University, Rampur, complements his professional endeavors. His accolades, such as the Most Inspirational Ambassador of the 29th Eco-generation Regional Ambassador and the Hidden Eco Hero Award from UNEP, highlight his contributions to climate advocacy and environmental education. Throughout his career, Sagar has held influential positions, such as Executive Board Member of the Nepal US Alumni Network and Regional Youth Focal Point at the World Food Forum. His diverse roles reflect a deep commitment to fostering sustainable development, empowering the next generation, and addressing global challenges through collaborative and innovative approaches.

name: Shreya KC
description:
Hi! I am Shreya KC, a passionate climate justice activist from Nepal. I have collaborated with young people worldwide to advocate for youth involvement in decision-making and climate education. Currently, I serve as the Advocacy Coordinator for the Loss and Damage Youth Coalition, leading campaigns and building youth capacity on climate-induced loss and damage. I also manage projects and develop campaigns on clean energy and climate change as a Policy Advisor at Clean Energy Nepal. Additionally, I engage with global and local youth networks as a Youth Advisor for The Iris Project and mentor prize winners.
My previous roles include being a member of the EE 30 Under 30 program by North American Association for Environmental Education (NAAEE), and a Board Member at Clean Energy Nepal. I volunteered for the NDC Project at Care About Climate and worked with YOUNGO as the Contact Point for the Nationally Determined Contributions Working Group. I coordinated campaigns and served as a delegate for Mock COP26 and represented Nepal as a Youth Delegate at COP26 and COP25. I was a Youth Climate Change Champion for UNICEF, participated in various youth conferences, and worked on youth-led climate initiatives. My early career involved roles such as Network Coordinator and School and College Coordinator for NYCA Nepal, and I also taught science and environment at Himchuli English Higher Secondary School. Throughout my career, I have been committed to driving meaningful climate action and empowering young people to lead the charge in climate justice.
My story has been featured in 'Stone Soup for a Sustainable World' and '50 Girls Saving Our Planet.' In 2022, I received the 'Youth of the Year' award for my climate action efforts. In my spare time, I love reading, traveling to natural places, and catching up on sleep.
